pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 590, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 312, 386, 327]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 890, 415]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 430, 890, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 888, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 489, 555, 504]]<|/det|>
## Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 578]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer. Any rough working should be done in this booklet. Electronic calculators may be used. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 858, 90]]<|/det|>
A pendulum is set in motion and timed. The time measured for 20 complete swings is 30 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 597, 120]]<|/det|>
What is the time for one complete swing of the pendulum?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 695, 147]]<|/det|>
A \(0.67 \text{s}\) B \(0.75 \text{s}\) C \(1.5 \text{s}\) D \(3.0 \text{s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 176, 96, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 176, 626, 193]]<|/det|>
The graph shows how the speed of an object varies with time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 721, 223]]<|/det|>
At which point on the graph is the greatest distance travelled per second?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 234, 764, 399]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 428, 96, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 428, 789, 445]]<|/det|>
An athlete runs at a speed of \(8 \text{m/s}\) for 10s, and then at a speed of \(6 \text{m/s}\) for 12s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 650, 476]]<|/det|>
Which calculation gives the average speed of the athlete in m/s?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 489, 141, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 488, 200, 518]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{8 + 6}{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 532, 141, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 530, 295, 564]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{(8\times 10) + (6\times 12)}{22}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 141, 598]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 577, 297, 610]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{(8\div 10) + (6\div 12)}{22}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 141, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 625, 300, 658]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{(10\div 8) + (12\div 6)}{22}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 691, 96, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 451, 707]]<|/det|>
Which quantity is measured in newtons?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 720, 213, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 745, 203, 760]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 769, 210, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 795, 210, 810]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 800, 195, 814]]<|/det|>
<label>work</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
An object is suspended from a spring balance on the Earth. The same object is suspended from the same spring balance on another planet.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 115, 650, 287]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 301, 675, 318]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains the difference between the two readings?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 140, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 330, 765, 348]]<|/det|>
Both the mass and the weight of the object are greater on the other planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 357, 140, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 357, 919, 389]]<|/det|>
The mass of the object is greater on the other planet than on Earth, but the weight is unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 397, 139, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 397, 636, 415]]<|/det|>
The spring stretches more easily when on the other planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 424, 139, 443]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 424, 919, 456]]<|/det|>
The weight of the object is greater on the other planet than on Earth, but the mass is unchanged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 483, 96, 501]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 483, 793, 500]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows four blocks of different metals. Each block has a mass of \(12\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 513, 422, 530]]<|/det|>
Which metal has the largest density?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 540, 766, 790]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 383, 90]]<|/det|>
Which is an example of a force?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 215, 116]]<|/det|>
**A** density

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 200, 141]]<|/det|>
**B** mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 215, 167]]<|/det|>
**C** volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 210, 193]]<|/det|>
**D** weight

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 222, 96, 240]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 378, 238]]<|/det|>
A car moves along a level road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 644, 269]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows all of the horizontal forces acting on the car.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 280, 822, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 394, 349, 409]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 357, 437]]<|/det|>
**A** The car is slowing down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 348, 463]]<|/det|>
**B** The car is speeding up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 474, 472, 489]]<|/det|>
**C** The car is moving at a constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 400, 515]]<|/det|>
**D** The car is moving backwards.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 545, 96, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 918, 576]]<|/det|>
Point X is the centre of mass of a lamina in the shape of a triangle with sides of equal length. The top of the triangle is cut off along the dotted line shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 587, 636, 757]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 770, 450, 786]]<|/det|>
What happens to the centre of mass, X?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 799, 470, 814]]<|/det|>
**A** moves towards the bottom of the page

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 825, 293, 840]]<|/det|>
**B** moves to the left

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 852, 304, 866]]<|/det|>
**C** moves to the right

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 877, 440, 892]]<|/det|>
**D** moves towards the top of the page

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 718, 90]]<|/det|>
Which device is designed to convert chemical energy into kinetic energy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 296, 117]]<|/det|>
A an a.c. generator

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 351, 143]]<|/det|>
B a battery-powered torch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 259, 168]]<|/det|>
C a car engine

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 383, 194]]<|/det|>
D a wind-up mechanical clock

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 223, 107, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 223, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
Which two physical quantities must be used to calculate the power developed by a student running up a flight of steps?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 266, 590, 282]]<|/det|>
A force exerted and the vertical height of the steps only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 292, 460, 308]]<|/det|>
B force exerted and the time taken only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 318, 568, 334]]<|/det|>
C work done and the vertical height of the steps only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 344, 437, 360]]<|/det|>
D work done and the time taken only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 390, 107, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 732, 406]]<|/det|>
A simple mercury barometer is used to measure the atmospheric pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 613, 435]]<|/det|>
Which height is measured to find the atmospheric pressure?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 444, 635, 677]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 706, 107, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 706, 748, 723]]<|/det|>
The particles of a gas, in a container of fixed volume, are given more energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 450, 752]]<|/det|>
Which effect does this have on the gas?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 763, 608, 780]]<|/det|>
A Both the pressure and temperature of the gas increase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 790, 504, 806]]<|/det|>
B Only the temperature of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 816, 635, 832]]<|/det|>
C Neither the pressure nor temperature of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 842, 477, 858]]<|/det|>
D Only the pressure of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 635, 90]]<|/det|>
A manometer is used to measure the pressure of a gas supply.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 100, 715, 256]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 268, 520, 285]]<|/det|>
Which change gives a greater value of height \(h?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 297, 365, 390]]<|/det|>
A using a less dense liquid B using a more dense liquid C using a narrower tube D using a wider tube

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 418, 107, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 418, 675, 435]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows apparatus being used to observe smoke particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 588, 465]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 shows how a smoke particle moves randomly.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 476, 885, 740]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 753, 490, 769]]<|/det|>
Why do the smoke particles move randomly?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 781, 395, 797]]<|/det|>
A They are hit by air molecules.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 807, 393, 823]]<|/det|>
B They are less dense than air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 833, 484, 849]]<|/det|>
C They are moved by convection currents.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 860, 415, 876]]<|/det|>
D They gain energy from the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 522, 90]]<|/det|>
The metal lid on a glass jar is difficult to unscrew.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
The jar is placed in a warm oven until the jar and the lid reach the same temperature. The lid is now easily unscrewed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 395, 164]]<|/det|>
Which property accounts for this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 177, 368, 193]]<|/det|>
A thermal capacity of the jar

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 203, 366, 219]]<|/det|>
B thermal capacity of the lid

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 230, 312, 245]]<|/det|>
C thermal conduction

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 255, 307, 270]]<|/det|>
D thermal expansion

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 300, 107, 318]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 918, 332]]<|/det|>
Two cold metal containers X and Y are both filled with the same mass of hot water at the same temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 401, 361]]<|/det|>
Both containers are well insulated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 374, 694, 391]]<|/det|>
The thermal capacity of container X is greater than that of container Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 666, 421]]<|/det|>
How do the final temperatures of the water in X and in Y compare?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 433, 489, 450]]<|/det|>
A The temperature in X is higher than in Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 482, 476]]<|/det|>
B The temperature in X is lower than in Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 485, 904, 501]]<|/det|>
C The temperatures in X and in Y are equal but lower than the initial temperature of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 511, 840, 527]]<|/det|>
D The temperatures in X and in Y are the same as the initial temperature of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 107, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 555, 918, 587]]<|/det|>
Some of the Sun's radiation passes through a prism. The diagram shows the spectrum of the radiation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 623, 616]]<|/det|>
Which point on the screen does the infra-red radiation reach?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 628, 845, 858]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 527, 90]]<|/det|>
Which statement about convection is not correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 636, 119]]<|/det|>
A It enables water in a pan on a cooker to get evenly heated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 415, 144]]<|/det|>
B It happens in liquids and gases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 353, 170]]<|/det|>
C It means that heat rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 178, 709, 195]]<|/det|>
D It occurs because the density of a fluid decreases when it is heated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 223, 107, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 223, 525, 241]]<|/det|>
What is meant by the frequency of a water wave?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 252, 588, 268]]<|/det|>
A the distance between consecutive crests of the wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 278, 527, 294]]<|/det|>
B the distance moved by the wave per unit time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 544, 320]]<|/det|>
C the maximum vertical displacement of the wave

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 561, 346]]<|/det|>
D the number of crests passing a point per unit time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 374, 107, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 374, 919, 407]]<|/det|>
Plane water waves travel from a shallow region into a deeper region. They travel more quickly in the deeper water.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 416, 668, 530]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 620, 560]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the wave pattern in the deeper water?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 570, 920, 692]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>22</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows two plane mirrors at \(90^{\circ}\) to each other. A ray of light is incident on one of the mirrors. The ray reflects off both mirrors before reaching a screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 564, 136]]<|/det|>
At which labelled point does the ray reach the screen?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[320, 146, 675, 405]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 433, 107, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>23</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 433, 918, 465]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the formation of a real image of an object O placed in front of a converging lens?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 475, 887, 827]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>24</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|>
Different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum are used for different purposes. Below are four statements about parts of the spectrum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 117, 762, 135]]<|/det|>
statement 1: Infra-red waves are used in television remote controllers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 144, 918, 161]]<|/det|>
statement 2: Radio waves are used to transmit television pictures from satellites to Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 171, 675, 187]]<|/det|>
statement 3: Ultraviolet waves are used for intruder alarms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[173, 196, 591, 212]]<|/det|>
statement 4: X-rays are used for security checks.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 225, 372, 242]]<|/det|>
<pre>Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 253, 140, 271]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 253, 220, 271]]<|/det|>
1 and 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 253, 384, 271]]<|/det|>
B 1 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 253, 551, 271]]<|/det|>
C 2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 253, 718, 271]]<|/det|>
D 3 and 4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 299, 107, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>25</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 299, 492, 316]]<|/det|>
Which statement about ultrasound is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 150, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 327, 651, 345]]<|/det|>
Ultrasound must have greater amplitude than audible sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 150, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 354, 651, 370]]<|/det|>
Ultrasound must have greater frequency than audible sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 136, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 380, 636, 396]]<|/det|>
Ultrasound must have lower amplitude than audible sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 406, 136, 424]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 406, 636, 422]]<|/det|>
Ultrasound must have lower frequency than audible sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 450, 107, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 510, 467]]<|/det|>
An iron bar PQ is placed close to a bar magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 479, 623, 497]]<|/det|>
In which diagram does end P become an induced north pole?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 507, 814, 713]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a bar magnet at rest on a smooth horizontal surface. A length of soft-iron wire is held parallel to the magnet. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[297, 114, 695, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 260, 290, 276]]<|/det|> The wire is released. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 291, 250, 307]]<|/det|> What happens? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 319, 139, 336]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 319, 479, 336]]<|/det|> The wire moves away from the magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 345, 139, 363]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 345, 457, 362]]<|/det|> The wire moves towards the magnet. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 139, 390]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 373, 918, 405]]<|/det|> The wire's centre stays in its present position and the wire rotates through \(90^{\circ}\) in a clockwise direction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 414, 139, 432]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 414, 918, 446]]<|/det|> The wire's centre stays in its present position and the wire rotates through \(90^{\circ}\) in an anticlockwise direction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 473, 107, 491]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 473, 816, 491]]<|/det|> A negatively charged plastic rod P is placed above a positively charged plastic rod Q. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 501, 618, 577]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 590, 719, 606]]<|/det|> What are the directions of the electrostatic forces on rod P and on rod Q? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 618, 540, 762]]<|/det|>
electrostatic force on rod Pelectrostatic force on rod Q
Adownwardsdownwards
Bdownwardsupwards
Cupwardsdownwards
Dupwardsupwards

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> The diagrams show the readings on an ammeter in a series circuit before and after the switch in the circuit has been closed. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 115, 804, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 282, 604, 300]]<|/det|> What is the current in the circuit when the switch is closed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 310, 700, 329]]<|/det|> **A** 3.2A **B** 3.4A **C** 3.6A **D** 3.8A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 357, 107, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 357, 507, 374]]<|/det|> A student investigates the resistance of a lamp. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 386, 564, 404]]<|/det|> Which row states how the meters must be connected? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 654, 543]]<|/det|>
ammetervoltmeter
Ain parallel with the lampin parallel with the lamp
Bin parallel with the lampin series with the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 270, 703, 287]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 491, 107, 508]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 920, 523]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a horizontal wire between the two magnetic poles of a U-shaped magnet. The U-shaped magnet is on a balance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 536, 638, 553]]<|/det|> When the switch closed, the reading on the balance decreases. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 562, 835, 744]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 755, 780, 772]]<|/det|> The experiment is carried out three more times with the following changes made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 784, 460, 802]]<|/det|> 1 Only the current is reversed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 811, 515, 828]]<|/det|> 2 Only the magnetic field is reversed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 836, 800, 854]]<|/det|> 3 Both the current and the magnetic field are reversed at the same time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 866, 656, 884]]<|/det|> Which changes cause an increase in the reading on the balance? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 895, 758, 912]]<|/det|> **A** 1 only **B** 2 only **C** 3 only **D** 1 and 2 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 291, 494, 308]]<|/det|>
The coil consists of 20 turns of insulated wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 322, 633, 338]]<|/det|>
The coil is connected to a variable resistor and a power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 352, 546, 368]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 580, 396]]<|/det|>
**A** by moving the poles of the magnet closer to the coil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 407, 794, 423]]<|/det|>
**B** by reducing the number of turns on the coil while keeping the current constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 573, 448]]<|/det|>
**C** by increasing the resistance of the variable resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 534, 475]]<|/det|>
**D** by reversing the terminals of the power supply
